docs.lead_paragraph: Implanting defibrillators in patients just weeks after a heart attack does not improve their chances of survival, according to an international study. The researchers suggested instead that patients wait several months before having one of the devices inserted in the chest. The findings could have big implications for Medicare, which is about to expand coverage for the $25,000 devices to many more people.

headline.main: Defibrillators Are Rethought In a New Study

docs.abstract: International study finds that implanting defibrillators in patients just weeks after heart attack does not improve their chances of survival; researchers suggest instead that patients wait several months before having one of devices inserted in chest; findings could have big implications for Medicare, which is about to expand coverage for $25,000 devices to many more people (M)
docs.snippet: Implanting defibrillators in patients just weeks after a heart attack does not improve their chances of survival, according to an international study.

docs.lead_paragraph: About 1,350 electrical workers at the Jersey Central Power and Light Company went on strike yesterday in a dispute over health care costs. After 12 hours of negotiations failed to produce a new contract, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers agreed with the company to halt talks. The company called in managers with previous experience or training as line workers. In September, the company offered a 9 percent wage increase over three years, but the union rejected it, the utility's president, Stephen E. Morgan, said. The main issue is how much employees and retirees must pay for health insurance coverage. No new talks were scheduled.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Electrical Workers Strike

docs.abstract: About 1,350 electrical workers go on strike against Jersey Central Power and Light Co in dispute over health care costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Help for Hanukkah Through Dec. 15, Sharon Lebewohl, an owner of the Second Avenue Deli, has a Hanukkah hot line for questions about menus and recipes. It is available from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. at (866) 542-2489. Gifted Eating Making edible holiday gifts, including chocolate truffles and flavored vinegars, will be taught on Saturday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at Camaje, 85 Macdougal Street (Bleecker Street), with plenty of extras to take home for giving. The fee is $75 for one person, $125 for two: (212) 673-8184. For a Good Cause A fund-raising party for Joannie Chen, who works for Blue Moon Fish in the Union Square Greenmarket, will be held on Monday from 5:30 to 10 p.m. at the Living Room, 154 Ludlow Street (Stanton Street). Ms. Chen, who has leukemia, has no health insurance. There will be music, a silent auction and food from the restaurants Tocqueville and the Minnow. There is no admission fee but a donation of $10 is requested. Fancy, Free Free tastings of caviar and smoked fish will be held at the Wild Edibles fish market in the Grand Central Market on Dec. 13 from 4 to 7:30 p.m.; at 535 Third Avenue (35th Street) on Dec. 14 from 4 to 8 p.m.; at 1216 Lexington Avenue (83rd Street) on Dec. 15 from 4 to 7:30 p.m.; and in the new store at 252 Bleecker Street (Leroy Street) on Dec. 16 from 5:30 to 8 p.m. On Dec. 17, from 5 to 8 p.m., a tasting will be held at Winfield-Flynn, a wine shop at 558 Third Avenue (37th Street). Reservations: (212) 213-9017. Christmas From the Sea This year a number of restaurants will serve a Neapolitan feast of seven fishes for Christmas Eve. Among them are San Domenico, 240 Central Park South, which will offer a five-course fish dinner Dec. 20 to 26, $70 per person. The Christmas Eve menu at Aquagrill, 210 Spring Street (Avenue of the Americas), will be eight courses for $75. And Abboccato, 136 West 55th Street, will also have an eight-course menu on Christmas Eve, $85. Three fish courses plus dessert at Marco New York, 142 West 10th Street, will be $50 on Christmas Eve. In Park Slope, Brooklyn, the Minnow, 442 Ninth Street (Seventh Avenue), will also serve an eight-course Christmas Eve fish dinner (seven courses plus dessert), $45 per person. A Vietnamese-style feast of seven fishes will be served at Bao 111, 111 Avenue C (Seventh Street), for $79. These dinners do not include beverages, tax and tip. FLORENCE FABRICANT

docs.lead_paragraph: I.B.M. Announces a Deal For Sale of PC Business I.B.M. announced the sale of its personal computer business to Lenovo of China in a $1.75 billion deal in cash, stock and debt. Under Lenovo's ownership, I.B.M.'s personal computer business will continue to be based in the United States and run by its current management team. I.B.M. will take just under a 20 percent stake in Lenovo. [Page A1.] Cisco Expects to Meet Estimates Dennis Powell, left, the chief financial officer of Cisco, told analysts that revenue at the company, which makes networking equipment, would grow annually on the higher end of the 10 percent to 15 percent range through 2008. Mr. Powell also said he expects the company to experience some downward pressure on its gross margins in the next several years. [C4.] Hewlett Considered a Split-Up Carleton S. Fiorina said that on three occasions the board of Hewlett-Packard considered breaking up the company, but each time it decided to keep it together. [C4.] Spitzer Vows No Letup on Inquiries The announcement by Eliot Spitzer that he will run for governor of New York had Wall Street executives cracking jokes, but Mr. Spitzer said he would not let up on current inquiries. [C2.] Supreme Court Hears Wine Issue The Supreme Court heard arguments on the shipment of wine from other states. [A1.] Gap Trying to Right Old Navy The fall fashion assortment at the Old Navy unit of Gap was not innovative enough, creating problems for the company. [C2.] Merck to Study Handling of Vioxx The board of Merck has appointed a special committee of seven outside directors to investigate whether the company acted properly regarding Vioxx, the arthritis treatment the company withdrew from the market in September. Shares of Merck have fallen nearly 40 percent since Vioxx was withdrawn. [C6.] Calpers Discloses Pay for Advisers The California Public Employees Retirement System disclosed how much it pays the venture capitalists, hedge fund managers and others who handle its riskiest specialized investments, and how well those investments have performed. [C6.] Cigna Agrees to Pay Connecticut Cigna Health Care agreed to pay Connecticut $870,388 as a result of what the state's attorney general referred to as ''improper payments of insurance commissions'' over the last 14 years on dental coverage for state workers. [C7.] Overcoming the Energy Impasse A group of environmentalists, academics and former government officials plans to offer ways to make the country cleaner and less vulnerable to energy shocks. [C2.] U.S. to Offer More Flu Vaccine As many as four million doses of flu vaccine from abroad will be used to ease the shortage in the United States. [A22.] Stocks Fall on Mixed Economic Data The Dow Jones industrials slid 106.48 points, to 10,440.58; the Standard & Poor's 500 lost 13.18 points, to 1,177.07; and the Nasdaq composite declined 36.59 points, to 2,114.66. [C7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge in Albany yesterday rejected the claims by 13 gay and lesbian couples that they have the right to marry under the state's Constitution. It was the second ruling in two months against plaintiffs in six separate civil suits seeking state recognition of same-sex marriage. In yesterday's ruling, Justice Joseph C. Teresi of State Supreme Court ruled that the 13 couples had not been denied their rights to equal protection under the laws, due process or freedom of speech by being thwarted in their attempts to marry.

headline.main: State Justice Rules Against 13 Couples Seeking Same-Sex Marriage

docs.abstract: New York State Supreme Court Justice Joseph C Teresi rules that 13 same-sex couples have not been denied rights to equal protection by not being allowed to marry; couples had hoped to be married by New Paltz Mayor Jason West, who officiated at more than two dozen such unions in February and has become controversial figure in national debate over same-sex marriage (M)
docs.snippet: A judge in Albany yesterday rejected the claims by 13 gay and lesbian couples that they have the right to marry under the state's Constitution.

docs.lead_paragraph: State lawmakers passed a bill last night to treat the death of a Bronx firefighter killed in combat in Iraq as a Fire Department line-of-duty death, paving the way for his family to receive city death benefits. The legislation will allow the widow of the firefighter, Christian Philip Engeldrum, who was killed on Nov. 29 while serving as a sergeant with the Army National Guard, to receive an annual pension benefit equal to his full salary, a lump sum known as a mayor's benefit equal to one year's salary and health insurance for her and their two sons for life, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Gov. George E. Pataki praised the Senate and Assembly for passing the measure and said he would sign it into law. ''Whether it was fighting fires on the streets of New York City or fighting terrorists in Iraq, Sergeant Engeldrum worked every day to protect his fellow citizens,'' Mr. Pataki said. Al Baker (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Full Benefits For Family Of Firefighter Killed In Iraq

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature passes bill to treat death of Bronx (NYC) firefighter and Army National Guard sergeant Christian Philip Engeldrum in Iraq as Fire Department line-of-duty death, giving his family New York City death benefits (S)

byline.original: By Al Baker (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: Cigna Health Care agreed yesterday to pay $870,388 to Connecticut as a result of what the state's attorney general called improper payments of insurance commissions over the last 14 years on dental coverage for state workers. The money -- reimbursement of commissions plus interest -- was collected amid wide-ranging investigations into the insurance industry by attorneys general and state insurance regulators throughout the country. Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general, said the money was not part of a settlement and that his investigation into Cigna Health Care and its parent, Cigna Corporation, was continuing.

headline.main: Cigna Will Reimburse Connecticut for Insurance Commissions

docs.abstract: Cigna Health Care agrees to pay $870,388 to Connecticut as result of what Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal called improper payments of insurance commissions over last 14 years on dental coverage for state workers (M)
docs.snippet: Cigna Health Care agreed yesterday to pay $870,388 to Connecticut as a result of what the state's attorney general called improper payments of insurance commissions over the last 14 years on dental coverage for state workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer, the two-term New York State attorney general who has gained a national reputation uncovering corrupt practices throughout the financial and insurance industries, said yesterday that he would run for governor in 2006, and pledged to fix what he called the ''crisis'' of New York's dysfunctional government. Mr. Spitzer's announcement might have been a formality, since he long ago signaled his intention to run, but it served to firm up his position nearly two years in advance as the likely Democratic nominee, making it easier to raise money, line up endorsements and build momentum.

headline.main: With Little Fanfare, Spitzer Says He Will Run for Governor in 2006

docs.abstract: New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer, in low-keyed announcement, says he will run for governor in 2006 to address 'crisis' of New York's dysfunctional government; photo; biographical details; two-term attorney general, who has won national reputation for uncovering corruption in financial and insurance industries, firms up early position as likely Democratic nominee, making it easier to raise money, line up endorsements and build momentum; Republican incumbent George Pataki ousted Mario Cuomo decade ago but is mired in gridlocked state government and says he has not decided whether to run again (M)
docs.snippet: Eliot Spitzer, the two-term New York State attorney general, said yesterday that he would run for governor in 2006.
